newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian shares ease, Western investors hang back.
newsitem.headline: Russian shares ease, Western investors hang back.

text.p: Leading Russian shares closed slightly down on moderate volumes on Friday and dealers said investor cautiousness would keep the market quiet and relatively unchanged next week.
The Russian Trading System 23-share index closed down to 294.94 from Thursday's 298.24 on total trade volume of $29.3 million.
"There's a lot of uncertainty -- everyone is waiting until someone begins to do something," said one Western trader.
National power utility UES EESR.RTS had edged up to $0.2095 after $0.2080 on Thursday.

Natural gas monopoly Gazprom GAZP.RTS had slipped to $0.630 as the market prepared to close after finishing on Thursday at $0.647. But Gazprom was up from a low of $0.618 in early Friday afternoon trade.
Russia's largest oil producer LUKoil LKOH.RTS also nudged down $13.400 at 6 p.m. (1400 GMT) from $13.570.
"The volumes in individual securities don't look bad, but the number of clients trading is not very big," said UCB head trader Samit Yakovlev.
Dealers said that caution among Western investors wondering if the U.S. Federal Reserve would raise interest rates again was pressuring the Russian market.
Data indicating a strong U.S. economy on Friday led some analysts to think that another interest rate hike was possible. The Fed last raised rates on March 25.
"Everything depends on the rise in interest rates in May, although I think that whatever happens, there will be a stabilisation in May because everybody will be ready for it by then," said Yakovlev.
Traders said they did not expect the market to fall sharply in the next few days.
"It's more likely levels will continue as they are," Yakovlev said.
